content.description: This long, pumpy, left leaning crack is an area classic and will ensure that you have no skin left on your fingers when you leave Whiskey. Start as low as possible on the right end of the crack. Using positive pods in the crack, heel and toe hooks, and as many energy-conserving techniques as you can, follow the long crack to its end.
content.protection: Quite a few pads. The landing is very poor at the beginning and 2/3 of the way through. The climber is never more than 5 feet off the ground, fortunately.
content.location: Beneath the imposing roof of Vulture View Rock, but on a separate boulder. Located directly on the trail from the Entrance Area. Obvious crack rising right to left. Walk off.

content.description: Climb up the left-center face of the tall slab, between the left arete and the big lichen patch.  The climbing is very fun with a great sequence of moves.  It's a tall problem, but the climbing gets easier as you go up.I don't know what the original name of this route was, so I called it "Unknown V1 Slab" for now. If anyone has any information about the name, let me know.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter due to the height of the problem but thankfully the landing area is flat
content.location: Just a bit beyond Whiskey Crack and around the corner from the prominent highball roof problem.

content.description:
This problem follows a blocky rail before entering a left leaning crack. Full of interesting moves, this is a nice warmup or intro to the area. 

  Start sitting with hands matched on the vertical rail. Make one hard move to stand up, then continue up towards the crack, liebacking it to the top and an easy mantle.
content.location: Located on the Platex Boulder, a square freestanding boulder less than 100 feet beyond Vulture View Rock. Follows a rail and crack on the side of the boulder facing the Cranking Area, right next to where the AT rejoins the ridge.

content.description: This is a nice quick easy warm up and a good problem for first time outdoor climbers. Easy moves up the crack. The crux is probably underclining the flake but it's a pretty simple move. Use the features to the left of the crack and then focus on the flake on the second half of the lightning bolt shaped crack.
content.protection: No pro, just a couple boulder pads.
content.location: Follow the climbers trail to the Whiskey Crack and blue paintings on the wall near the Grand Traverse. Continue straight past between the two routes. You should see a lightning-bolt shaped crack to the right of a straight crack where the Vulture-View ledge ends. Send that lightning bolt. The route starts on a two hand ledge to the left of the crack at standing level. The route finishes at the top of the flake. The best way to come down is to shuffle along the boulder about ten feet to the right and slide down. There should be little crimp-rails along the way down. The easiest way off is to hop down from the small ledge onto a rock below, be careful coming down!

content.description: Start matched on the huge shelf, then move up through crimps and slopers to a sketchy topout.
content.protection: 1 pad over the backbreaker below the topout should do it.
content.location: The overharning boulder down and right of Whiskey Crack

content.description:
The Grand Traverse moves across Vulture View Rock from left to right. The climbing is varied and features a nice rest. It is part of a very contrived larger traverse of most of the central area of Whiskey. 

  Start under the far left end of the enormous roof. Climb delicately rightward on small crimps (crux) to gain a wide crack in the center of the face below the roof. Jam or layback this 10 feet up and continue traversing on the juggy horizontal. A rest ledge can be found at the right corner of the roof where the horizontal ends. From here, the problem traverses a tricky slab. With sparse hands, walk your feet down and across the rail-like features. Once across the slab, climb the chimney to the top of the rock and enjoy a warm beer.
content.protection: Pad for the crimp crux and the slab.
content.location: Starts beneath the enormous Vulture View overhang and continues rightward around the corner.

content.description: On the other side of the whiskey crack boulder and just above Mantle Man, find the chalked low shelf.  Start heel hooked on that shelf with a lower jug undercling and an edge for your hands.  Perform a difficult sequence to round the corner then climb the delicate face to a heady mantle topout.
content.location: Near Whiskey crack and Mantle Man, just below Vulture View

content.description: The central area of Whiskey, located between the Entrance and Cranking areas. Loosely defined as the boulders around the highest rock, but extending west towards Bob Dylan Did Drugs. Home to a series of highballs and moderates, several of which are contrived.
